channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Republican lawmakers in Indiana vote down Trump's congressional redistricting push
item.description: The state Senate in Indiana defeated a plan to redraw the voting map, in a way that could have flipped two House seats. This was despite months of pressure from President Trump.
item.content:encoded: The state Senate in Indiana defeated a plan to redraw the voting map, in a way that could have flipped two House seats. This was despite months of pressure from President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ben Thorp

item.title: What 2026 might look like for Democrats
item.description: Democrats are feeling optimistic about their chances to retake the House of Representatives next year, but they also face challenges in their efforts to push back on President Trump.
item.content:encoded: Democrats are feeling optimistic about their chances to retake the House of Representatives next year, but they also face challenges in their efforts to push back on President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Mara Liasson

item.title: Here's what made it onto this year's UNESCO intangible cultural heritage list
item.description: Each year, UNESCO recognizes culturally significant practices, traditions and customs. 2025's list includes weaving, handmade paper craftsmanship, yurt making, a genre of Cuban music and yodeling.
item.content:encoded: Each year, UNESCO recognizes culturally significant practices, traditions and customs. 2025's list includes weaving, handmade paper craftsmanship, yurt making, a genre of Cuban music and yodeling.
item.dc:creator: Avery Keatley

item.title: The best volunteers are the ones who are committed and always show up
item.description: A retired nurse knew that many families in her community struggle to afford diapers, so she picked a volunteer job where she could really help.
item.content:encoded: A retired nurse knew that many families in her community struggle to afford diapers, so she picked a volunteer job where she could really help.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Keith

item.title: An exoplanet, how ant colonies deal with disease and a volcanoes-Black Death link
item.description: Regina Barber and Emily Kwong of NPR's Short Wave discuss an Earth-sized exoplanet, how ant colonies deal with disease and a possible link between volcanoes and the Black Death.
item.content:encoded: Regina Barber and Emily Kwong of NPR's Short Wave discuss an Earth-sized exoplanet, how ant colonies deal with disease and a possible link between volcanoes and the Black Death.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kwong

item.title: Trump administration indefinitely suspends immigration requests for Afghan nationals
item.description: The Trump administration indefinitely suspended the processing of immigration requests for Afghans, potentially setting back tens of thousands of Afghans seeking asylum or other paths to citizenship.
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration indefinitely suspended the processing of immigration requests for Afghans, potentially setting back tens of thousands of Afghans seeking asylum or other paths to citizenship.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Schneider

item.title: 'Catastrophe bonds' are gaining popularity as a response to climate change
item.description: After the hurricane in Jamaica, the government had a pot of money to help rebuild. A Catastrophe Bonds payout. We explain how it works and why Cat Bond popularity is on the rise as a response to climate change.
item.content:encoded: After the hurricane in Jamaica, the government had a pot of money to help rebuild. A Catastrophe Bonds payout. We explain how it works and why Cat Bond popularity is on the rise as a response to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Guo

item.title: Foreign-born population shrinks as Trump administration pressures immigrants to go
item.description: The Trump administration claims 2 million non-citizens departed the U.S. this year, mostly "voluntarily." We examine its pressure tactics, including ICE raids and arrests at green card appointments.
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration claims 2 million non-citizens departed the U.S. this year, mostly "voluntarily." We examine its pressure tactics, including ICE raids and arrests at green card appointments.
item.dc:creator: Martin Kaste

item.title: Venezuela: What's next for the opposition and U.S. pressure on the regime?
item.description: After more than a year in hiding, Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado surfaces in Oslo, as the U.S. seizes an oil tanker near Venezuela.
item.content:encoded: After more than a year in hiding, Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado surfaces in Oslo, as the U.S. seizes an oil tanker near Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: From Venezuela to Ukraine, Trump is shaking up American diplomacy around the world
item.description: On this week's episode of Sources & Methods, NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks to correspondents Greg Myre and Eleanor Beardsley about the future of the U.S. alliance with Europe under President Trump.
item.content:encoded: On this week's episode of Sources & Methods, NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks to correspondents Greg Myre and Eleanor Beardsley about the future of the U.S. alliance with Europe under President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly
